knife 0.5.0 documentation

knife Documentation

Contents   ::   knife.lazy.lazyknife — Lazily evaluated combo knife  »

knife Documentation¶

knife is a powerful multitool loosely inspired by ‘underscore.js <http:// documentcloud.github.com/underscore/>`_ but remixed for Python. It concentrates functionality from Python standard library in modules like itertools, collections <http://docs.python. org/library/collections.html>_, operator <http://docs.python.org/library/ operator.html>_ in one convenient shrink-wrapped package.

Vitals¶

knife‘s documentation can be found at http://knife.readthedocs.org/ or http://packages.python.org/knife/

knife works with Python 2.6, 2.7, and 3.2.

Installation¶

knife can be installed with pip:

$ pip install knife [... stuff happens ...] Successfully installed knife

Or easy_install:

$ easy_install knife [... stuff happens ...] Finished processing dependencies for knife

knife can also be downloaded from http://

Development¶

  • knife public source repository is at https://bitbucket.org/lcrees/knife.
  • knife is mirrored on https://github.com/kwarterthieves/knife/.
  • knife issues can be reported at https://bitbucket.org/lcrees/knife/issues
  • knife is distributed under a BSD license.

In Brief...¶

knife features 45 carefully curated methods that can be chained together into one pipeline.

Higly contrived introductory example:

>>> from knife import __
>>> __(5, 4, 3, 2, 1).initial().rest().slice(1, 2).last().get()
3

Or used in object-oriented style.

Higly contrived introductory example:

>>> from knife import knife
>>> oo = knife(('a', 1), ('b', 2), ('c', 3))
>>> oo.wrap(dict)
>>> oo.map()
>>> oo.get()
{'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': 3}

knife‘s methods are also available in more modular classes that can be chained together in pipelines.

Higly contrived introductory example:

>>> from knife.active import mathknife, reduceknife
>>> one = mathknife(10, 5, 100, 2, 1000)
>>> two = reduceknife()
>>> one.minmax().pipe(two).merge().back().min().get()
2

knife can also rollback the results of previous operations, a baseline snapshot, or its original arguments.

Higly contrived introductory example:

>>> undone = __(1, 2, 3).prepend(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6)
>>> undone.peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3]
>>> undone.append(1).undo().peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3]
>>> undone.append(1, 2).undo(2).peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3, 1]
undone.snapshot().append(1, 2).baseline().peek()
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 1, 2, 3, 1]
undone.original().peek()
[1, 2, 3]
>>> one.original().minmax().pipe(two).merge().back().max().get()
1000
>>> one.original().minmax().pipe(two).merge().back().sum().get()
1002

knife‘s knives come in two flavors: active and mod:lazy. Active knives evaluate the result of each operation upon method invocation. Lazy knives are more lazily evaluated when a knife is iterated over or get() method is called to fetch the results.

There is an active combo knife featuring all :mod:knife’s method that can be imported as:

>>> from knife import knife

Or:

>>> from knife import activeknife

There is a lazy combo knife that can be imported as a “dunderscore” (two underscores).

>>> from knife import __

Or:

>>> from knife import lazyknife

Specilized classes featuring a limited subset of knife functionality` are available in active or lazy flavors and documented below:
